Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Situation2: They witness a serious wrongdoing, such as corruption or harm to others, and feel compelled to take decisive moral action.
Story:
I was scrubbing the marble floors in the hotel lobby, my gloved hands moving in practiced circles. The scent of disinfectant clung to my skin, a reminder of the strict hygiene rules I was expected to follow. My supervisor always said, “Gloves on, always. No exceptions.” But sometimes, when the work was light, I slipped them off for comfort, just for a moment.

Today, as I wiped down the reception desk, I overheard two managers whispering. Their words were sharp, urgent—something about hiding evidence of a guest’s injury, blaming it on the guest instead of a broken tile. My heart pounded. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand for dharma, to act with honesty and protect others from harm. But if I spoke up, I’d have to admit I wasn’t always following the safety protocols myself. Would they listen to me, or turn the blame on my own lapses? The weight of my gloves felt heavier than ever, caught between my duty to my job and my duty to my conscience.
